With the increase of \( I \), \( r \) increases, but \( r \) cannot be equal to or greater than the critical angle \( C \)

In the figure, for any point on the sphere, the normal of the sphere must pass through the center of the sphere. Let \( R \) be the angle of refraction when light enters from point A, and \( i' \) be the angle of incidence when light exits from point B. They are the two base angles of an isosceles triangle, so there is \( i' = r \). \( r \) cannot be equal to or greater than the critical angle \( C \), so \( i' \) cannot be equal to or greater than the critical angle, that is, when light exits from point B, total reflection cannot happen. The light will not be totally reflected when it is emitted from the inside of the sphere.
